title: Enemybot: A Look into Keksec's Latest DDoS Botnet

meta.title: Enemybot: A Look into Keksec's Latest DDoS Botnet

sentences.html: By

sentences.html: Joie Salvio

chapters.title: Enemybot: A Look into Keksec's Latest DDoS Botnet

sentences.text: Affected Platforms: Linux<crlf>Impacted Users: Any organization<crlf>Impact: Remote attackers gain control of the vulnerable systems<crlf>Severity Level: Critical
sentences.html: Affected Platforms: Linux Impacted Users: Any organization Impact: Remote attackers gain control of the vulnerable systems Severity Level: Critical

sentences.text: In mid-March, FortiGuard Labs observed a new DDoS botnet calling itself Enemybot and attributing itself to Keksec, a threat group that specializes in cryptomining and DDoS attacks.
sentences.html: In mid-March, FortiGuard Labs observed a new DDoS botnet calling itself “Enemybot” and attributing itself to Keksec, a threat group that specializes in cryptomining and DDoS attacks.

sentences.text: This botnet is mainly derived from Gafgyts source code but has been observed to borrow several modules from Mirais original source code.
sentences.html: This botnet is mainly derived from Gafgyt’s source code but has been observed to borrow several modules from Mirai’s original source code.

sentences.text: It uses several methods of obfuscation for its strings to hinder analysis and hide itself from other botnets. Furthermore, it connects to a command-and-control (C2) server that is hidden in the Tor network, making its takedown more complicated.
sentences.html: It uses several methods of obfuscation for its strings to hinder analysis and hide itself from other botnets. Furthermore, it connects to a command-and-control (C2) server that is hidden in the Tor network, making its takedown more complicated.

sentences.text: Enemybot has been seen targeting routers from Seowon Intech, D-Link, and exploits a recently reported iRZ router vulnerability to infect more devices.
sentences.html: Enemybot has been seen targeting routers from Seowon Intech, D-Link, and exploits a recently reported iRZ router vulnerability to infect more devices.

sentences.text: This blog details how this malware leverages these vulnerabilities and the commands it can execute once inside an infected device.
sentences.html: This blog details how this malware leverages these vulnerabilities and the commands it can execute once inside an infected device.

sentences.text: One of the first things Enemybot does is to drop a file in /tmp/.pwned, containing a message that attributes itself to Keksec. In earlier samples, this message was stored as cleartext. Only a few days after, a new sample was released with the message encoded with an XOR operation using a multiple-byte key. This suggests that this malware is being actively developed.
sentences.html: One of the first things Enemybot does is to drop a file in /tmp/.pwned, containing a message that attributes itself to Keksec. In earlier samples, this message was stored as cleartext. Only a few days after, a new sample was released with the message encoded with an XOR operation using a multiple-byte key. This suggests that this malware is being actively developed.

sentences.text: A sample, SHA256: fec09b614d67e8933e2c09671e042ce74b40048b5f0feed49ba81a2c18d4f473, captured on March 24, 2022 has the message in cleartext:
sentences.html: A sample, SHA256: fec09b614d67e8933e2c09671e042ce74b40048b5f0feed49ba81a2c18d4f473, captured on March 24, 2022 has the message in cleartext:

sentences.text: ENEMEYBOT V3.1-ALCAPONE hail KEKSEC
sentences.html: “ENEMEYBOT V3.1-ALCAPONE hail KEKSEC”

sentences.text: A sample from March 28, 2022 SHA256: 93706966361922b493d816fa6ee1347c90de49b6d59fc01c033abdd6549ac8b9, encoded the message with an XOR operation using a multi-byte key.
sentences.html: A sample from March 28, 2022 SHA256: 93706966361922b493d816fa6ee1347c90de49b6d59fc01c033abdd6549ac8b9, encoded the message with an XOR operation using a multi-byte key.

sentences.text: Upon decoding, the message has also been changed to:
sentences.html: Upon decoding, the message has also been changed to:

sentences.text: ENEMEYBOT V3.1-ALCAPONE - hail KEKSEC, ALSO U GOT haCkED MY [REDACTED] (Your device literally has the security of a [shitty device] / [smart doorbell])
sentences.html: “ENEMEYBOT V3.1-ALCAPONE - hail KEKSEC, ALSO U GOT haCkED MY [REDACTED] (Your device literally has the security of a [shitty device] / [smart doorbell])”

sentences.text: Figure 1: Code snippet from decoding .pwned message
sentences.html: Figure 1: Code snippet from decoding .pwned message

sentences.text: Subsequently, FortiGuard Labs researchers discovered newer samples that reverted to the cleartext versions of the /tmp/.pwned message, which might suggest the possibility of multiple developers working with different versions of the codebase or having different programming habits.
sentences.html: Subsequently, FortiGuard Labs researchers discovered newer samples that reverted to the cleartext versions of the /tmp/.pwned message, which might suggest the possibility of multiple developers working with different versions of the codebase or having different programming habits.

sentences.text: Keksec is known for operating multiple botnets, some of which are based on Gafgyt (a.k.a. Bashlite). Gafgyt is a DDoS botnet whose source code was leaked way back in 2015.
sentences.html: Keksec is known for operating multiple botnets, some of which are based on Gafgyt (a.k.a. Bashlite). Gafgyt is a DDoS botnet whose source code was leaked way back in 2015.

sentences.text: In the case of Enemybot, although it is mainly based on Gafgyt, it was observed that some of its modules are clearly borrowed from Mirais source code. One of these is Enemybots scanner module as shown in the screenshots below.
sentences.html: In the case of Enemybot, although it is mainly based on Gafgyt, it was observed that some of its modules are clearly borrowed from Mirai’s source code. One of these is Enemybot’s scanner module as shown in the screenshots below.

sentences.text: Figure 2: Obvious code similarities between Mirai and Enemybots scanner modules
sentences.html: Figure 2: Obvious code similarities between Mirai and Enemybot’s scanner modules

sentences.text: Another module shared with Mirai is the bot killer module where it searches for any running processes started from certain file paths or with specific keywords in its process memory. It then terminates these processes. Enemybot enhances the original Mirai code with over sixty keywords to identify and kill off any competitors running on the same devices.
sentences.html: Another module shared with Mirai is the bot killer module where it searches for any running processes started from certain file paths or with specific keywords in its process memory. It then terminates these processes. Enemybot enhances the original Mirai code with over sixty keywords to identify and kill off any competitors running on the same devices.

sentences.text: While researching this botnet, FortiGuard Labs observed that Enemybot shares several similarities with Gafgyt_tor previously reported by other researchers, and assessed that Enemybot is likely an updated and rebranded variant of Gafgyt_tor.
sentences.html: While researching this botnet, FortiGuard Labs observed that Enemybot shares several similarities with Gafgyt_tor previously reported by other researchers, and assessed that Enemybot is likely an updated and “rebranded” variant of Gafgyt_tor.

sentences.text: Infects Multiple Architectures
sentences.html: Infects Multiple Architectures

sentences.text: Like most botnets, this malware infects multiple architectures to increase its chances of infecting more devices. In addition to IoT devices, Enemybot also targets desktop/server architectures such as BSD, including Darwin (macOS), and x64.
sentences.html: Like most botnets, this malware infects multiple architectures to increase its chances of infecting more devices. In addition to IoT devices, Enemybot also targets desktop/server architectures such as BSD, including Darwin (macOS), and x64.

sentences.text: Enemybot targets the following architectures:
sentences.html: Enemybot targets the following architectures:

sentences.text: arm<crlf>arm5<crlf>arm64<crlf>arm7<crlf>bsd<crlf>darwin<crlf>i586<crlf>i686<crlf>m68k<crlf>mips<crlf>mpsl<crlf>ppc<crlf>ppc-440fp<crlf>sh4<crlf>spc<crlf>x64<crlf>x86

sentences.text: Enemybots download server was previously misconfigured and displayed a list of ELF binaries for different architectures (Figure 3). Threat actors have fixed this at the time of writing.
sentences.html: Enemybot’s download server was previously misconfigured and displayed a list of ELF binaries for different architectures (Figure 3). Threat actors have fixed this at the time of writing.

sentences.text: Figure 3: Open directory of Enemybots download server
sentences.html: Figure 3: Open directory of Enemybot’s download server

sentences.text: Obfuscation
sentences.html: Obfuscation

sentences.text: Enemybot obfuscates strings in a variety of ways: C2 domain uses XOR encoding with a multi-byte key Credentials for SSH brute-forcing and bot killer keywords use Mirai-style encoding, i.e., single byte XOR encoding with 0x22 Commands are encrypted with a substitution cipher, i.e,, swapping one character for another Some strings are encoded by just adding three to the numeric value of each character<crlf>C2 domain uses XOR encoding with a multi-byte key<crlf>Credentials for SSH brute-forcing and bot killer keywords use Mirai-style encoding, i.e., single byte XOR encoding with 0x22<crlf>Commands are encrypted with a substitution cipher, i.e,, swapping one character for another<crlf>Some strings are encoded by just adding three to the numeric value of each character
sentences.html:
• Enemybot obfuscates strings in a variety of ways:
    • C2 domain uses XOR encoding with a multi-byte key
    • Credentials for SSH brute-forcing and bot killer keywords use Mirai-style encoding, i.e., single byte XOR encoding with 0x22
    • Commands are encrypted with a substitution cipher, i.e,, swapping one character for another
    • Some strings are encoded by just adding three to the numeric value of each character

sentences.text: While these obfuscation techniques are simplistic, they are sufficient to hide tell-tale indicators of its presence from casual analysis and other botnets. Most IoT botnets including Enemybot are known for searching for such indicators to terminate other botnets running on the same device.
sentences.html: While these obfuscation techniques are simplistic, they are sufficient to hide tell-tale indicators of its presence from casual analysis and other botnets. Most IoT botnets including Enemybot are known for searching for such indicators to terminate other botnets running on the same device.

sentences.text: Infecting More Devices
sentences.html: Infecting More Devices

sentences.text: In terms of spreading, Enemybot uses several methods that have also been observed in other IoT botnet campaigns.
sentences.html: In terms of spreading, Enemybot uses several methods that have also been observed in other IoT botnet campaigns.

sentences.text: One way is using a list of hardcoded username/password combinations to login into devices configured with weak or default credentials. This is another module that was copied from Mirais source code.
sentences.html: One way is using a list of hardcoded username/password combinations to login into devices configured with weak or default credentials. This is another module that was copied from Mirai’s source code.

sentences.text: This malware also tries to run shell commands to infect misconfigured Android devices that expose Android Debug Bridge port (5555).
sentences.html: This malware also tries to run shell commands to infect misconfigured Android devices that expose Android Debug Bridge port (5555).

sentences.text: The last method is to target devices with specific vulnerabilities as listed below:
sentences.html: The last method is to target devices with specific vulnerabilities as listed below:

sentences.text: CVE-2020-17456 is a vulnerability that targets SEOWON INTECH SLC-130 and SLR-120S routers. Malicious commands can be injected into the pingIPAddr parameter (Figure 4)
sentences.html: • CVE-2020-17456 is a vulnerability that targets SEOWON INTECH SLC-130 and SLR-120S routers. Malicious commands can be injected into the pingIPAddr parameter (Figure 4)

sentences.text: Figure 4: CVE-2020-17456 exploit request
sentences.html: Figure 4: CVE-2020-17456 exploit request

sentences.text: Another vulnerability (no CVE assigned) targets the Seowon SLC-130 router. This is similar to the previous exploit, only this time the command could be injected in the vulnerable queriesCnt parameter. The implementation was likely based on publicly available exploit code.
sentences.html: • Another vulnerability (no CVE assigned) targets the Seowon SLC-130 router. This is similar to the previous exploit, only this time the command could be injected in the vulnerable queriesCnt parameter. The implementation was likely based on publicly available exploit code.

sentences.text: Figure 5: Another exploit targeting Seowon SLC-130 router
sentences.html: Figure 5: Another exploit targeting Seowon SLC-130 router

sentences.text: CVE-2018-10823 is an older D-Link router vulnerability that allows an authenticated user to execute a malicious command into the Sip parameter of the chkisg.htm page (Figure 6). The following devices are affected by this vulnerability. DWR-116 through 1.06 DWR-512 through 2.02 DWR-712 through 2.02 DWR-912 through 2.02 DWR-921 through 2.02 DWR-111 through 1.01<crlf>DWR-116 through 1.06<crlf>DWR-512 through 2.02<crlf>DWR-712 through 2.02<crlf>DWR-912 through 2.02<crlf>DWR-921 through 2.02<crlf>DWR-111 through 1.01
sentences.html:
• CVE-2018-10823 is an older D-Link router vulnerability that allows an authenticated user to execute a malicious command into the Sip parameter of the chkisg.htm page (Figure 6). The following devices are affected by this vulnerability.
    • DWR-116 through 1.06
    • DWR-512 through 2.02
    • DWR-712 through 2.02
    • DWR-912 through 2.02
    • DWR-921 through 2.02
    • DWR-111 through 1.01

sentences.text: D-Link provided updated firmware for some of the above-mentioned devices. Its recommended to check and update these devices if they still have vulnerable versions.
sentences.html: D-Link provided updated firmware for some of the above-mentioned devices. It’s recommended to check and update these devices if they still have vulnerable versions.

sentences.text: Figure 6: CVE-2018-10823 exploit request
sentences.html: Figure 6: CVE-2018-10823 exploit request

sentences.text: CVE-2022-27226 is a recent vulnerability on iRZ mobile routers that was exploited by Enemybot shortly after it was published on March 19, 2022. In fact, this is the first botnet observed by FortiGuard Labs to target devices from this vendor.
sentences.html: • CVE-2022-27226 is a recent vulnerability on iRZ mobile routers that was exploited by Enemybot shortly after it was published on March 19, 2022. In fact, this is the first botnet observed by FortiGuard Labs to target devices from this vendor.

sentences.text: This vulnerability allows an attacker to execute a command by adding a crontab entry in the infected device via the /api/crontab (Figure 7).
sentences.html: This vulnerability allows an attacker to execute a command by adding a crontab entry in the infected device via the /api/crontab (Figure 7).

sentences.text: Figure 7: CVE-2022-27226 exploit request
sentences.html: Figure 7: CVE-2022-27226 exploit request

sentences.text: During the past few weeks, FortiGuard Labs researchers also observed different samples adding and removing exploits. A list of these exploits seen in use by Enemybot for propagation are as follows:
sentences.html: During the past few weeks, FortiGuard Labs researchers also observed different samples adding and removing exploits. A list of these exploits seen in use by Enemybot for propagation are as follows:

sentences.text: CVE-2022-25075 to 25084: Targets TOTOLINK routers, previously exploited by the Beastmode botnet<crlf>CVE-2021-44228/2021-45046: Better known as Log4j, more details are available on our Fortinet PSIRT blog<crlf>CVE-2021-41773/CVE-2021-42013: Targets Apache HTTP servers<crlf>CVE-2018-20062: Targets ThinkPHP CMS<crlf>CVE-2017-18368: Targets Zyxel P660HN routers<crlf>CVE-2016-6277: Targets NETGEAR routers<crlf>CVE-2015-2051: Targets D-Link routers<crlf>CVE-2014-9118: Targets Zhone routers<crlf>NETGEAR DGN1000 exploit (No CVE assigned): Targets NETGEAR routers
sentences.html:
• CVE-2022-25075 to 25084: Targets TOTOLINK routers, previously exploited by the Beastmode botnet
  • CVE-2021-44228/2021-45046: Better known as Log4j, more details are available on our Fortinet PSIRT blog
  • CVE-2021-41773/CVE-2021-42013: Targets Apache HTTP servers
  • CVE-2018-20062: Targets ThinkPHP CMS
  • CVE-2017-18368: Targets Zyxel P660HN routers
  • CVE-2016-6277: Targets NETGEAR routers
  • CVE-2015-2051: Targets D-Link routers
  • CVE-2014-9118: Targets Zhone routers
  • NETGEAR DGN1000 exploit (No CVE assigned): Targets NETGEAR routers

sentences.text: This mix of exploits targeting web servers and applications beyond the usual IoT devices, coupled with the wide range of supported architectures, might be a sign of Keksec testing the viability of expanding the botnet beyond low-resource IoT devices for more than just DDoS attacks. Based on their previous botnet operations, using them for cryptomining is a big possibility.
sentences.html: This mix of exploits targeting web servers and applications beyond the usual IoT devices, coupled with the wide range of supported architectures, might be a sign of Keksec testing the viability of expanding the botnet beyond low-resource IoT devices for more than just DDoS attacks. Based on their previous botnet operations, using them for cryptomining is a big possibility.

sentences.text: After a successful exploit, a shell command is executed to download another shell script from a URL. In most cases, particularly in Mirai-based botnets, this URL is hardcoded. In the case of Enemybot however, this URL is dynamically updated by the C2 server via the command LDSERVER. The clear advantage of this method is that when the download server is down for whatever reason, the botnet operators can just update the bot clients with a new URL.
sentences.html: After a successful exploit, a shell command is executed to download another shell script from a URL. In most cases, particularly in Mirai-based botnets, this URL is hardcoded. In the case of Enemybot however, this URL is dynamically updated by the C2 server via the command LDSERVER. The clear advantage of this method is that when the download server is down for whatever reason, the botnet operators can just update the bot clients with a new URL.

sentences.text: The shell script update.sh then downloads the actual Enemybot binaries compiled for every architecture it targets and executes them.
sentences.html: The shell script update.sh then downloads the actual Enemybot binaries compiled for every architecture it targets and executes them.

sentences.text: Figure 8: Code snippet from update.sh
sentences.html: Figure 8: Code snippet from update.sh

sentences.text: Commands and DDoS capabilities
sentences.html: Commands and DDoS capabilities

sentences.text: Once the bot gets installed on a victims device, it connects to its C2 server and waits for further commands. The C2 server hides in the Tor network and the bot tries to access the server using a hardcoded list of SOCKS proxy IPs.
sentences.html: Once the bot gets installed on a victim’s device, it connects to its C2 server and waits for further commands. The C2 server hides in the Tor network and the bot tries to access the server using a hardcoded list of SOCKS proxy IPs.

sentences.text: This bot supports several commands listed in the following table.
sentences.html: This bot supports several commands listed in the following table.

sentences.text: Based on the analysis of FortiGuard Labs, Enemybot is Keksecs latest tool for performing DDoS attacks.
sentences.html: Based on the analysis of FortiGuard Labs, Enemybot is Keksec’s latest tool for performing DDoS attacks.

sentences.text: To protect itself, it uses simple obfuscation techniques on its strings as well as hosting its C2 server in the Tor network, taking advantage of the networks anonymity. It uses several techniques commonly found in other DDoS botnet malware to infect other devices.
sentences.html: To protect itself, it uses simple obfuscation techniques on its strings as well as hosting its C2 server in the Tor network, taking advantage of the network’s anonymity. It uses several techniques commonly found in other DDoS botnet malware to infect other devices.

sentences.text: Seeing how this malware has undergone changes during the research for this article, we expect that more updated versions will be distributed in the wild soon.
sentences.html: Seeing how this malware has undergone changes during the research for this article, we expect that more updated versions will be distributed in the wild soon.

sentences.text: FortiGuard Labs will keep monitoring this botnet.
sentences.html: FortiGuard Labs will keep monitoring this botnet.

sentences.html: Fortinet customers are protected by the following:

sentences.text: The FortiGuard Antivirus service detects and blocks this threat as ELF/Gafgyt, Linux/Gafgyt, and Linux/Mirai<crlf>FortiGuard Labs provides IPS signatures against attacks exploiting the following vulnerabilities: CVE-2022-27226 - iRZ.Mobile.Router.API.crontab.AUTH.Remote.Code.Execution CVE-2021-44228/2021-45046 - Apache.Log4j.Error.Log.Remote.Code.Execution CVE-2021-41773/CVE-2021-42013 - Apache.HTTP.Server.cgi-bin.Path.Traversal CVE-2020-17456 - Seowon.Intech.Routers.system_log.CGI.Command.Injection Seowon SLC-130 Vulnerability RCE (vulnerable queriesCnt parameter) - Seowon.Intech.Routers.Unauthenticated.Remote.Code.Execution CVE-2018-20062 - ThinkPHP.Controller.Parameter.Remote.Code.Execution CVE-2018-10823 - D-Link.DWR.CVE-2018-10823.Remote.Code.Execution CVE-2017-18368 - TrueOnline.ZyXEL.P660HN.V1.Unauthenticated.Command.Injection CVE-2016-6277 - NETGEAR.WebServer.Module.Command.Injection CVE-2015-2051 - D-Link.Devices.HNAP.SOAPAction-Header.Command.Execution Netgear DGN1000 exploit (No CVE) - NETGEAR.DGN1000.CGI.Unauthenticated.Remote.Code.Execution<crlf>CVE-2022-27226 - iRZ.Mobile.Router.API.crontab.AUTH.Remote.Code.Execution<crlf>CVE-2021-44228/2021-45046 - Apache.Log4j.Error.Log.Remote.Code.Execution<crlf>CVE-2021-41773/CVE-2021-42013 - Apache.HTTP.Server.cgi-bin.Path.Traversal<crlf>CVE-2020-17456 - Seowon.Intech.Routers.system_log.CGI.Command.Injection<crlf>Seowon SLC-130 Vulnerability RCE (vulnerable queriesCnt parameter) - Seowon.Intech.Routers.Unauthenticated.Remote.Code.Execution<crlf>CVE-2018-20062 - ThinkPHP.Controller.Parameter.Remote.Code.Execution<crlf>CVE-2018-10823 - D-Link.DWR.CVE-2018-10823.Remote.Code.Execution<crlf>CVE-2017-18368 - TrueOnline.ZyXEL.P660HN.V1.Unauthenticated.Command.Injection<crlf>CVE-2016-6277 - NETGEAR.WebServer.Module.Command.Injection<crlf>CVE-2015-2051 - D-Link.Devices.HNAP.SOAPAction-Header.Command.Execution<crlf>Netgear DGN1000 exploit (No CVE) - NETGEAR.DGN1000.CGI.Unauthenticated.Remote.Code.Execution<crlf>The FortiGuard Web Filtering Service blocks downloaded URLs.
sentences.html:
• The FortiGuard Antivirus service detects and blocks this threat as ELF/Gafgyt, Linux/Gafgyt, and Linux/Mirai
  • FortiGuard Labs provides IPS signatures against attacks exploiting the following vulnerabilities:
    • CVE-2022-27226 - iRZ.Mobile.Router.API.crontab.AUTH.Remote.Code.Execution
    • CVE-2021-44228/2021-45046 - Apache.Log4j.Error.Log.Remote.Code.Execution
    • CVE-2021-41773/CVE-2021-42013 - Apache.HTTP.Server.cgi-bin.Path.Traversal
    • CVE-2020-17456 - Seowon.Intech.Routers.system_log.CGI.Command.Injection
    • Seowon SLC-130 Vulnerability RCE (vulnerable “queriesCnt” parameter) - Seowon.Intech.Routers.Unauthenticated.Remote.Code.Execution
    • CVE-2018-20062 - ThinkPHP.Controller.Parameter.Remote.Code.Execution
    • CVE-2018-10823 - D-Link.DWR.CVE-2018-10823.Remote.Code.Execution
    • CVE-2017-18368 - TrueOnline.ZyXEL.P660HN.V1.Unauthenticated.Command.Injection
    • CVE-2016-6277 - NETGEAR.WebServer.Module.Command.Injection
    • CVE-2015-2051 - D-Link.Devices.HNAP.SOAPAction-Header.Command.Execution
    • Netgear DGN1000 exploit (No CVE) - NETGEAR.DGN1000.CGI.Unauthenticated.Remote.Code.Execution
  • The FortiGuard Web Filtering Service blocks downloaded URLs.

sentences.text: FortiGuard IP Reputation & Anti-Botnet Security Service proactively blocks these attacks by aggregating malicious source IP data from the Fortinet distributed network of threat sensors, CERTs, MITRE, cooperative competitors, and other global sources that collaborate to provide up-to-date threat intelligence about hostile sources.
sentences.html: FortiGuard IP Reputation & Anti-Botnet Security Service proactively blocks these attacks by aggregating malicious source IP data from the Fortinet distributed network of threat sensors, CERTs, MITRE, cooperative competitors, and other global sources that collaborate to provide up-to-date threat intelligence about hostile sources.

sentences.text: FortiGuard Application Control Service provides organizations the capability to monitor or block access to malicious, risky, or unwanted applications. Customers without specific business requirements for Tor can refer to these Fortinet Technical Tips for blocking inbound and outbound Tor traffic using the Application Control Service.
sentences.html: FortiGuard Application Control Service provides organizations the capability to monitor or block access to malicious, risky, or unwanted applications. Customers without specific business requirements for Tor can refer to these Fortinet Technical Tips for blocking inbound and outbound Tor traffic using the Application Control Service.
